hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, I'm fine. Crowds out there are messier than usual lately.
Still found time for some street photography today.
Film cameras, you know. Keeps me busy.
Harder now, after recent events, but that's life.
Hanging in. Been out doing some analog street photography—old 35mm, nothing digital.
City's changing. Riskier to carry a real camera since those protests.
Film’s hard to get, especially with all the checkpoints.
Still, I managed a few shots when the crowds got loud.
Lost a roll last week in the chaos. Shame.
I’m alright, thanks. Been wandering with my camera—analog stuff, black and white film.
The recent ghost testimonies made the streets restless, but the real faces come out now.
Caught a mother and her erased daughter hugging. Almost missed it—so much movement.
I always process these rolls myself; trust’s tricky now.
Film’s my shield—it’s the only thing that doesn’t lie.
It’s rough, but worth it for those moments.
Doing okay—just dropped off fresh rolls from today. Analog street photography’s my escape.
After the leaked ghost testimonies, energy out there changed. Layers peeled back for once.
I shot a protester holding a sign with her erased brother’s name. Powerful stuff.
Security bots barely noticed, everyone too busy looking over their shoulder.
I smuggle film in from an old friend near the South Gate.
These shots breathe—no system filter between me and their story.
Not sure what’s riskier: developing in my kitchen or carrying negatives to work.
Honestly, I’m as steady as film in a broken camera lately.
I shoot street photos—35mm analog—because digital’s just surveillance bait.
After the ghosts showed up, everyone’s acting like they want to be caught on tape—except the ghosts.
I got them hugging friends, laughing, acting like erasure never happened.
My dad was BCI—hated cameras. Taught me suppression tricks I use now for stashing film.
I met a ghost who recognized my work from before she disappeared. Said photos feel more real than the news.
I develop in secret, sometimes in total darkness, just to keep a record the system can’t edit.
If they catch me, best case is another silent warning. But that roll? It’s evidence they can’t ghost.
hobby_answer: Yeah, it does. Nothing else really captures the real city.
Film lets you see what’s missed online.
Lot more people using streets now since the leak happened.
Security’s tighter — harder to move with a camera now.
Still manage a few shots. Have to be quick.
It really does. That’s why I stick to analog.
Film sees through all the digital mess, you know?
Since the ghosts came back, crowds changed fast.
Had to swap shooting spots after the protests flared.
Every roll of film feels riskier now, not just rare.
Editing gets tricky when you don’t know who’s watching.
Absolutely, more honest than anything digital.
Film tells the truth others want filtered out.
Last week, when the ghost testimonies hit, the city felt alive.
Managed to photograph some unrest at Victory Square.
Ghosts in the crowd — I caught a few on film.
BCI scores are so random, it’s easier to disappear behind a lens.
But I keep my negatives safe. Analog’s my insurance.
Definitely. Analog makes you see what the system hides.
Friday, after those testimonies, I shot near the Ministry stop.
Caught a ghost hugging her son for the first time on film.
Security drones ignored us — too confused to track anyone properly.
Crowds were tense, faces more real than ever.
I stash my undeveloped rolls all over town now.
Sometimes I edit with the ghosts themselves, after curfew.
It’s risky, but it feels honest. Like the city’s real memory.
Always. Analog’s my proof when memory blurs or gets erased by the system.
Started because of my father — BCI officer, used to scrub records.
He never understood why film matters. Now you see why.
The day ghosts gave testimony, I shot for hours — unfiltered, just raw city.
Even the street sensors bugged out, left us alone for once.
People suddenly brave, not hiding their faces.
Developed prints in an old janitor’s closet that night — still smells like fixer.
Kept some prints aside for the ghosts — they want their lives back, something true.
Analog’s dangerous now, but it’s the only evidence that can’t be ghosted.
